questions.prompt: The energy stored in a 10μF capacitor at 5V is:
questions.explanation: E = ½CV² = ½ × 10×10⁻⁶ × 25 = 125 μJ. Remember the ½ factor!

questions.prompt: The energy stored in a 2mH inductor carrying 3A is:
questions.explanation: E = ½Li² = ½ × 2×10⁻³ × 9 = 9 mJ. Energy is proportional to current squared.

questions.prompt: The lossless property states that over one period of periodic excitation:
options: Net energy entering C or L is zero
questions.correctAnswer: Net energy entering C or L is zero
questions.explanation: Since q(t) = q(t+T), the integral ∫v·dq from q₁ to q₁ = 0. Energy is borrowed and returned each cycle — no net consumption.

questions.prompt: Path independence of capacitor energy means:
options: Energy depends on the charging waveform shape
Energy depends only on initial and final charge (or voltage)
Energy is always the same regardless of capacitance
The path through the circuit doesn't matter
questions.correctAnswer: Energy depends only on initial and final charge (or voltage)
questions.explanation: w_C = ∫v(q)dq depends only on q₁ and q₂, not on v(t) or i(t). This is the mathematical essence of being lossless.

questions.prompt: In steady-state AC, the average power consumed by an ideal capacitor is:
questions.explanation: The lossless property ensures zero average power. V and I are 90° out of phase, so average P = VIcos(90°) = 0.

questions.prompt: A relaxation point q* is defined as a charge where:
questions.explanation: E(q*) = 0 and E(q) = ∫_{q*}^{q} v(q')dq' ≥ 0 for all q. The capacitor is 'fully relaxed' at q*.

questions.prompt: The three equivalent forms of capacitor energy are:
questions.explanation: E = ½CV² = ½Q²/C = ½QV, using Q = CV. All three are equivalent — choose whichever uses the given quantities.

questions.prompt: Why do real capacitors heat up slightly?
questions.explanation: Real capacitors have parasitic resistance (ESR) in leads and dielectric. This small resistance dissipates power as heat, especially at high ripple currents.

questions.prompt: The instantaneous power into a capacitor p_C(t) equals:
questions.explanation: p = v_C · i_C = v_C · C·dv_C/dt = d/dt[½Cv²]. Power is the rate of change of stored energy — positive when charging, negative when discharging.
E = ½ × 100×10⁻⁶ × 400² = ½ × 10⁻⁴ × 160000 = 8 J. Released in ~1ms, that's ~8kW peak power.
